items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 11:30 PM on 24/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, Arpley Bridge.
The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Arpley Bridge and at Eastford Road at 12:30 AM on 25/11/2022, which are 6.617 and 6.656 metres respectively and are expected to stay above flood alert level until approximately 2:00 AM.
Tidal level at Fiddlers Ferry will peak at 12:30 AM on 25/11/2022, at 6.55 metres, and will stay above flood alert level until approximately 1.00 AM.
After this tide no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 09:30 AM on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

As a result of high spring tides, flooding is possible along the Coast at North Morecambe Bay between 10:45 PM and Midnight on 24/11/2022. Flooding is possible one hour either side of this time.  Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.  Tides are expected to remain at Flood Alert levels into the weekend. We are not expecting to issue any Flood Warnings at this time. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads in the area. This message will be updated on 25/11/2022, 9:30AM or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 03:00 on 25/11/2022 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 93 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the nextÂ few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 25/11/2022, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Low pressure will cause sea levels to be higher than forecast in tide tables. First forecast high water is 19:15 on 24/11/22 with a level of 7.36 mAOD and a Force 5 south south westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 07:45 on 25/11/22 with a level of 7.36 mAOD and a Force 4 west north westly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and properties is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one/two to two/four hours either side of the high tide. We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.  
This message will be updated Friday, 25/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The forecast high water is between 06:00 PM and 07:00 PM on the 24th November with a total water level of 5.56mAOD at Chiswell and a Force 6 south westerley wind.  All times are local and refer to the high water times at Chiswell, mAOD is height above average sea level and for more detail please refer to local tide tables. items.message: Flooding is possible over the high tide on Thursday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 18:00. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Strong force 7 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 4.3m are forecast. Expect tides to be around 500mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions. These conditions are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.07 mAOD, this is 0.5 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Torksey and Gainsborough river gauges as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road, low lying land and the foreshore in the Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith areas.
We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow 25/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 25/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:32 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, although flood depths will be relatively shallow, and flooding will only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. After this tideâ the weather becomes more settledâ so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond and install drop boards to protect property. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 16:00 on 25/11/2022.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. This morning's tide at Cowes (10:45 on 24/11/2022) came in at 4.70 Chart Datum (2.11 mAOD). Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. For the rest of the week, tide levels will be lower than today. We are not expecting further impacts as a result.

items.message: The River Adur is higher than normal, but currently slowly falling. 5mm of rain was measured Thursday afternoon. Only brief showers are predicted Thursday night. The River Adur will rise again, but only a small amount, probably no higher than recent days. Minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads and the gardens of properties near Mock Bridge. River levels should begin to fall from 09:00 Friday (25/11/2022). A lot more rain is forecast Saturday evening (up to 50mm), which could cause property flooding. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on the 25/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains higher than normal. At Alverstone, the river level is falling by approximately 1cm an hour. Likewise, the level at Sandown is decreasing by approximately 1cm an hour. Residual flood impacts affecting roads, cycle tracks and footpaths throughout the Yar Valley will continue until tomorrow (25/11/2022). At Sandown, the ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Further rainfall (up to 15mm) is expected later this afternoon (24/11/2022). This may cause the river to rise again, but property flooding is not expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens and property from flooding are operating. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday 25/11/2022.

items.message: Flooding is possible on Thursday 24th November from late afternoon into the evening. Over the last several hours we have seen heavy rainfall and rivers in the Upper Tamar catchment are still rising. Further showers are forecast this evening. Expected levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Thursday evening, though no flooding to properties is currently forecast.  Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 11am on Friday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

The Western Rother is higher than normal between Midhurst and FIttleworth. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens. 5mm of rain was measured Thursday afternoon. Only brief showers are predicted Thursday night. Only a very small rise in river levels is expected along the Western Rother. Flooding of properties is not currently expected, with river levels predicted to fall during Friday (25/11/2022). However, a lot of rain is forecast Saturday evening (up to 50mm) which could cause property flooding along the length of the Western Rother. River levels might not return nearer to normal until next week. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on the 25/11/2022.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:30 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.19 m. The total forecast tide is 6.13 metres Chart Datum (3.08 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves will overtop the sea front. Water will flow westwards along Mill Lane and Climping Street (from the right of the East car park) ponding in Climping Street Car Park, near to properties, and in nearby land and fields.Â A very similar tide and flood impacts are forecast for midday Friday. Winds are predicted to ease Friday afternoon. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Our operations staff plan to work at the beach Friday morning. Please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. Avoid visiting the sea front. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 09:00 on 25/11/2022.

The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, following twice the monthly average rainfall in November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. 5mm of rain was measured Thursday afternoon. Only brief showers are predicted Thursday night. River levels will not rise by much (a few centimetres) Thursday evening and are expected to fall through Friday. In Barnham, only minimal impacts are currently expected, with river levels comparatively lower. Minimal rain is due on Friday. However a lot of rain is forecast Saturday evening (up to 50mm), which could cause river levels to rise even higher than their recent peak. We continue to monitor the situation and routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 25/11/2022.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:32 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high tide, water may just exceed the top of the main slipway, flooding the road at Lower Quay, Fareham. The lower end of Wallington Shore Road will flood to a depth of 0.1m. After this tideâ the weather becomes more settledâ so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We recommend that cars do not park at the lower end of Wallington Shore Road. We will update this message by 16:00 on 25/11/2022.

Thursday evening's tide at 23:32 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, spray overtopping of sea defence walls into low lying coastal roads between Hillhead and Gosport, namely Cliff Road and Stokes Bay Road is expected. At Hillhead, low lying Sea front car parks may flood. Property flooding is not expected. After this tideâ the weather becomes more settledâ so levels will reduce and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Be careful if driving, parking or walking at Gosport sea front at high tide. We will update this message by 16:00 on 25/11/2022.

For 1 hour either side of high water, in Old Portsmouth, the tide may just exceed the top of the main slipway which will cause minor road flooding in East Street and to the boat yards at The Camber. items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: Heavy rain on Monday 21 November has caused river levels to rise on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the river will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding at North Bank Road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media.

River levels have risen at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore and low lying land at Quedgeley / Stonebench. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.5m and 3.8m Tuesday morning, 29/11/22.
We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am on 25/11/22 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Thursday evening's tide at 23:32 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. High energy waves are expected, which could deplete the shingle and force large amounts of water up the beach, overtopping splash walls and flood boards. For 2 hours either side of high water, this could flood property in Southwood Road. Beach huts at West Beach, near the Inn on the beach may also be affected. Water could reach the road at Sea Front, near the junction of St Andrew's Road. At 11:51 on Friday (25/11/2022)â the tide level remains elevated, but lower than Thursday evening. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are liaising with the local authority and their response teams over the condition of the beach at South Hayling. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by strong winds and large waves. We will update this message by 09:00 on 25/11/2022.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast today Thursday 24/11/22.  We expect river levels to remain high. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. This morning's tide at Portsmouth (11:09 on 24/11/2022) came in at 5.22 Chart Datum (2.49 mAOD). Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. However, tide levels will remain high over the next 24 hours. A Flood Alert will remain in force for Langstone to Emsworth Harbour.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Evenlode particularly between Broadwell and Evenlode as a result of persistent rainfall over the last week. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland will continue tonight, 24/11/22. We are currently experiencing rainfall in the area but are looking at a drier night and day tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high until at least tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this afternoon, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Thursday evening's tide at 23:30 on 24/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.19 m. The total forecast tide is 6.13 metres Chart Datum (3.08 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, waves will overtop the sea front. Water will flow westwards along Mill Lane and Climping Street (from the right of the East car park) ponding in Climping Street Car Park, near to properties, and in nearby land and fields. A very similar tide and flood impacts are forecast for midday Friday. Winds are predicted to ease Friday afternoon.  We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Our operations staff plan to work at the beach Friday morning. Please take action to protect property on Climping Street at least 2 hours before high tide. Avoid visiting the sea front. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 25/11/2022.
